qas.question: Why were former Sun staff members put in police custody in early 2012?

answers.text: as part of a probe in which journalists paid police officers for information

qas.question: What was the charge against those arrested?
What greater scandal was this investigation a part of?

answers.text: the News of the World scandal
crime editor Mike Sullivan, head of news Chris Pharo, former deputy editor Fergus Shanahan, and former managing editor Graham Dudman

qas.question: What role had Graham Dudman taken after serving as The Sun managing editor?

context: On 28 January 2012, police arrested four current and former staff members of The Sun, <a0_0>as part of a probe in which journalists paid police officers for information<a0_0/>; a police officer was also arrested in the probe. The Sun staffers arrested were <a3_0>crime editor Mike Sullivan, head of news Chris Pharo, former deputy editor Fergus Shanahan, and former managing editor Graham Dudman<a3_0/>, who since became a <a4_0>columnist and media writer<a4_0/>. All five arrested were held on <a1_0>suspicion of corruption<a1_0/>. Police also searched the offices of News International, the publishers of The Sun, as part of a continuing investigation into <a2_0>the News of the World scandal<a2_0/>.
